text: america's stock market is booming
corporate profits are up but although
the economy may be improving the gains
haven't been shared equally
31 year old morris royal and 7.25 cents
an hour working at burger king
not enough he says to be able to afford
anywhere to live i'm in a shelter right
now
so i'm in shouts i've been sheltered for
about a month now
um struggling uh trying to get special
assistance with food stamps and stuff
like that
and his frustration is shared by many
the fast food strikes that started in
new york over a year ago are expected to
spread to a hundred cities this thursday
they're calling for fifteen dollars an
hour more than double the national
minimum wage and they want the right to
form a union
but advocates for the restaurant
industry question who will pay for these
wage increases
the model of the fast food industry was
to provide a lot of jobs for people just
starting out at a low wage what it's not
designed to do is provide long-term
employment for many people over a long
period of time if we change that
business model be very difficult for
restaurants to stay open and provide the
employment that's become so important to
a large swath of the population
the growing gap between the rich and
poor hasn't escaped the attention of the
white house president obama describing
it as the defining challenge of our time
combined trends of increased inequality
and decreasing mobility pose a
fundamental threat to the american dream
our way of life and what we stand for
around the globe
the timing of such remarks is likely to
draw more attention to the protests
fast food jobs represent a growing part
of the economy so the challenge of
making ends meet on a low wage is really
beginning to hit home and that's why the
protests that started here in new york
are finding a wider audience
michelle fleury bbc news new york
